items.title: Krafton hikes India bet with new $670M fund
items.summary: Called the Unicorn Growth Fund, the investment vehicle is a collaboration between Krafton and South Korean internet conglomerate Naver, and investor Mirae Asset. It aims to deploy around $669.3 million over four years.

items.title: Engadget Podcast: 2025 was the year of AI, smartglasses and spineless Big Tech
items.summary: This week, Engadget Managing Editor Cherlynn Low joins us to look back at some of the highlights (and lowlights) of 2025. We dive into our favorite gadgets of the year, the many ways Big Tech bowed to Trump, the disappointment of AI PCs and the rise of smart glasses. We also learn way too much abouâ€¦

items.title: Apple age verification with a privacy focus would solve two problems
items.summary: While Apple is currently lobbying against being given a legal responsibility for age verification when it comes to downloading apps, I think the companyâ€™s customers would very much benefit from it taking on this role. Given the companyâ€™s track record in finding privacy-respecting approaches to persâ€¦

items.title: MasterClass deal: Get 50 percent off subscriptions for the holidays
items.summary: If learning a new skill is one of your New Year's resolutions, then you might want to know that MasterClass subscriptions are currently 50 percent off. This brings the top-tier subscription with offline mode and use on up to six devices down from $240 annually to $120. The entry-level plan, which sâ€¦

items.summary: The subscription channel takes over from the BBC which had been the principal partner since 1954 and provided free-to-air coverage.

items.title: Man City 'must prepare' for successor, says Guardiola
items.summary: Pep Guardiola says Manchester City "must be prepared" to plan for his departure and eventual successor.

items.title: Apple might be requiring iPhone users to install iOS 26 for security fixes
items.summary: Apple released iOS 26.2 last week with important security fixes. At the same time, it also shipped iOS 18.7.3 for users who havenâ€™t upgraded yet â€” at least in theory. In practice, Jason Snell at Six Colors reports that some iPhone owners arenâ€™t being offered the iOS 18 security update at all, and aâ€¦

items.title: OpenAI is reportedly trying to raise $100B at an $830B valuation
items.summary: The ChatGPT maker is aiming to raise the funding by the end of the first quarter in 2026, and the company may ask sovereign wealth funds to invest in the round.

items.title: The 12 best last-minute Christmas gifts for 2025 that will arrive by December 24

The holidays can truly sneak up on you, and this year thatâ€™s been more true than ever. items.title: A total League of Legends revamp is coming in 2027
items.summary: Riot Games has confirmed that itâ€™s working on a massive update for League of Legends after Bloomberg published a report saying that the company has plans to remake the game. Back in November, a Chinese esports insider also reported that a League of Legends 2 is in development and is coming as earlyâ€¦

items.title: From Helmand to Milan - Meenagh's quest for Winter Paralympic medal
items.summary: Scotland's Scott Meenagh is targeting a first medal at his third and final Winter Paralympics, 14 years on from losing both his legs in Helmand Province

items.title: Pick up the Samsung P9 microSD Express card for Switch 2 while it's down to a record low
items.summary: It was a big day in gaming history when Nintendo finally released its Switch sequel. But the Nintendo Switch 2 lacked many options for microSD Express cards. Samsung helped change that this fall, with the release of its P9 Express series of microSD Express cards, and now one of them is on sale. Curâ€¦

items.title: Heat pull off sensational record Big Bash chase
items.summary: Centuries from Matt Renshaw and Jack Wildermuth help Brisbane Heat chase a record 258 to beat Perth Scorchers in the Big Bash League.

items.title: macOS Tahoe users report persistent screen flickering issues
items.summary: If youâ€™ve noticed odd screen flickering since installing macOS Tahoe, youâ€™re not alone. A growing number of users are reporting brief but distracting display flickers, particularly when using Appleâ€™s Studio Display. moreâ€¦

items.title: Gloucester-bound Lake back to lead Ospreys
items.summary: Wales hooker Dewi Lake will return to captain Ospreys for their United Rugby Championship home match against Munster in Bridgend on Saturday.

items.title: 'Class act' - how BBC Radio 5 Live and Barmy Army have kept Adelaide tidy

items.title: Parasites plagued Roman soldiers at Hadrianâ€™s Wall
items.summary: They were infected by roundworm, whipworm, and microscopic protozoans called Giardia duodenalis.
items.body: It probably sucked to be a Roman soldier guarding Hadrianâ€™s Wall circa the third century CE. W.H. Auden imagined the likely harsh conditions in his poem â€œ Roman Wall Blues ,â€ in which a soldier laments enduring wet wind and rain with â€œlice in my tunic and a cold in my nose.â€ We can now add chronic nausea and bouts of diarrhea to his list of likely woes, thanks to parasitic infections, according to a new paper published in the journal Parasitology. As previously reported , archaeologists can learn a great deal by studying the remains of intestinal parasites in ancient feces. For instance, in 2022, we reported on an analysis of soil samples collected from a stone toilet found within the ruins of a swanky 7th-century BCE villa just outside Jerusalem. That analysis revealed the presence of parasitic eggs from four different species: whipworm, beef/pork tapeworm, roundworm, and pinworm. (Itâ€™s the earliest record of roundworm and pinworm in ancient Israel.) Later that same year, researchers from the University of Cambridge and the University of British Columbia analyzed the residue on an ancient Roman ceramic pot excavated at the site of a 5th-century CE Roman villa at Gerace, a rural dâ€¦

items.title: Trump commits to Moon landing by 2028, followed by a lunar outpost two years later
items.summary: Also, the Trump administration wants to put some nuclear power reactors there, too.
items.body: A couple of hours after a judge formally swore in private astronaut Jared Isaacman as the next administrator of NASA on Thursday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order outlining his space policy objectives for the next three years. The executive order, titled â€œ Ensuring American Space Superiority ,â€ states that the country must â€œpursue a space policy that will extend the reach of human discovery, secure the nationâ€™s vital economic and security interests, unleash commercial development, and lay the foundation for a new space age.â€ White House sets priorities There is nothing Earth-shattering in the new executive order, as much of it builds on previously announced policies that span multiple administrations. There are some notable points in the document that clearly reflect the White Houseâ€™s priorities, though, and Isaacmanâ€™s leadership of NASA. Read full article Comments

items.title: YouTube bans two popular channels that created fake AI movie trailers
items.summary: Google loves AI content, except when it doesn't.
items.body: Google is generally happy to see people using generative AI tools to create content, and itâ€™s doubly happy when they publish it on its platforms. But there are limits to everything. Two YouTube channels that attracted millions of subscribers with AI-generated movie trailers have been shuttered. Screen Culture and KH Studio flooded the site with fake but often believable trailers. The channels, which had a combined audience of more than 2 million subscribers, became a thorn in Googleâ€™s side in early 2025 when other YouTubers began griping about their sudden popularity in the age of AI. The channels produced videos with titles like â€œGTA: San Andreas (2025) Teaser Trailerâ€ and â€œMalcom In The Middle Reboot (2025) First Trailer.â€ Of course, neither of those projects exist, but that didnâ€™t stop them from appearing in user feeds. Google demonetized the channels in early 2025, forcing them to adopt language that made it clear they were not official trailers. The channels were able to monetize again, but the disclaimers were not consistently used. Indeed, many of the most popular videos from those channels in recent months included no â€œparodyâ€ or â€œconcept trailerâ€ disclosures. Now, visitinâ€¦

items.title: Peacock showing ads upon launch opens the door for more disruptive streaming ads
items.summary: Subscribers will start seeing ads when selecting a user next year.
items.body: Peacock subscribers will see ads immediately upon opening the streaming app or website next year. Itâ€™s a bold new strategy for attracting advertisersâ€”something thatâ€™s been increasingly important to subscription-based streaming servicesâ€”but it also risks alienating viewers As reported by Variety , the new type of ads will display on the profile selection page that shows when a subscriber launches Peacock. Starting next year, instead of the profile page just showing your different Peacock profiles, most of the page will be dominated by an advertorial image. The circles of NBCUniversal-owned characters selected for user profiles will be relegated to a vertical column on the screenâ€™s left side, as you can see here . To avoid seeing what NBCUniversal is calling â€œArrival Adsâ€ every time you open Peacock, you need to subscribe to Peacockâ€™s most expensive plan, which is ad-free and starts at $17 per month (Peacockâ€™s ad-based plans start at $8/month.) In the first week or so of the drive, over 300 readers have contributed nearly $18,000 to either the Electronic Frontier Foundation or Childâ€™s Play as part of the charity drive (Childâ€™s Play has a roughly 55/45 donation lead at the moment). Thatâ€™s still a long way from 2020â€™s record haul of over $58,000 , but thereâ€™s plenty of time until the Charity Drive wraps up on Friday, January 2, 2026. items.title: RAM and SSD prices are still climbingâ€”hereâ€™s our best advice for PC builders
items.summary: I would avoid building a PC right now, but if you can't, here's our best advice.
items.body: The first few months of 2025 were full of graphics card reviews where we generally came away impressed with performance and completely at a loss on availability and pricing. The testing in these reviews is useful regardless, but when it came to extra buying advice, the best we could do was to compare Nvidiaâ€™s imaginary pricing to AMDâ€™s imaginary pricing and wait for availability to improve. Now, as the year winds down, weâ€™re facing price spikes for memory and storage that are unlike anything Iâ€™ve seen in two decades of pricing out PC parts. Pricing for most RAM kits has increased dramatically since this summer, driven by overwhelming demand for these parts in AI data centers. Depending on what youâ€™re building, itâ€™s now very possible that the memory could be the single most expensive component you buy; things are even worse now than they were the last time we compared prices a few weeks ago . items.title: School security AI flagged clarinet as a gun. Exec says it wasnâ€™t an error.
items.summary: Human review didn't stop AI from triggering lockdown at panicked middle school.
items.body: A Florida middle school was locked down last week after an AI security system called ZeroEyes mistook a clarinet for a gun, reviving criticism that AI may not be worth the high price schools pay for peace of mind. Human review of the AI-generated false flag did not stop police from rushing to Lawton Chiles Middle School. Cops expected to find â€œa man in the building, dressed in camouflage with a â€˜suspected weapon pointed down the hallway, being held in the position of a shouldered rifle,'â€ a Washington Post review of the police report said. Instead, after finding no evidence of a shooter, cops double-checked with dispatchers who confirmed that a closer look at the images indicated that â€œthe suspected rifle might have been a band instrument.â€ Among panicked students hiding in the band room, police eventually found the suspect, a student â€œdressed as a military character from the Christmas movie Red One for the schoolâ€™s Christmas-themed dress-up day,â€ the Post reported. items.title: LLMsâ€™ impact on science: Booming publications, stagnating quality
items.summary: Once researchers turn to LLMs, paper counts go up, quality does not.
items.body: There have been a number of high-profile cases where scientific papers have had to be retracted because they were filled with AI-generated slop â€”the most recent coming just two weeks ago . These instances raise serious questions about the quality of peer review in some journalsâ€”how could anyone let a figure with terms like â€œrunctitional,â€ â€œfexcectorn,â€ and â€œfrymblalâ€ through, especially given the â€˜mâ€™ in frymblal has an extra hump? But it has not been clear whether these high-profile examples are representative. How significantly has AI use been influencing the scientific literature? A collaboration of researchers at Berkeley and Cornell have decided to take a look. Theyâ€™ve scanned three of the largest archives of pre-publication papers and identified ones that are likely to have been produced using Large Language Models. And they found that, while researchers produce far more papers after starting to use AI and the quality of the language used went up, the publication rate of these papers has dropped. Searching the archives The researchers began by obtaining the abstracts of everything placed in three major pre-publication archives between 2018 and mid-2024. At the arXiv, this netâ€¦

items.title: Neural DSP models John Mayerâ€™s entire amp and effects rigâ€”and it sounds great
items.summary: Mayer gets the "Archetype" treatment.
items.body: Guitarists today are spoiled for choice, and that goes doubly true for players who use computer-based amp modeling software. Iâ€™m one such player, and I donâ€™t miss the size, weight, deafening volume, or cost of owning an amp and cabinet collection, to say nothing of all those pedals and cables. For clean to mid-gain tones alone, I already have more terrific options than I need, including Neural DSPâ€™s Tone King and Cory Wong and Mateus Asato , Polychrome DSPâ€™s Lumos , and Universal Audioâ€™s new Paradise Guitar Studio . All work slightly differently, but they can each output record-ready tones that are really, really close to the (often incredibly expensive) hardware that they model, and they each give you plenty of great-sounding presets to start from. So do we really need one amp sim package? Neural DSP thinks we do, because the Finnish company just dropped a major new release yesterday called Archetype: John Mayer X . It doesnâ€™t model Mayerâ€™s type of gear but his actual hardware units, along with all the actual settings he uses in the studio and on stage. It even has some presets that he designed. Which is great if you want to sound like John Mayerâ€”but what does the software offer â€¦

items.title: NASA will soon find out if the Perseverance rover can really persevere on Mars
items.summary: Engineers at JPL are certifying the Perseverance rover to drive up to 100 kilometers.
items.body: When the Perseverance rover arrived on Mars nearly five years ago, NASA officials thought the next American lander to take aim on the red planet would be taking shape by now. At the time, the leaders of the space agency expected this next lander could be ready for launch as soon as 2026â€”or more likely in 2028. Its mission would have been to retrieve Martian rock specimens collected by the Perseverance rover, then billed as the first leg of a multilaunch, multibillion-dollar Mars Sample Return campaign. Here we are on the verge of 2026, and thereâ€™s no sample retrieval mission nearing the launch pad. In fact, no one is building such a lander at all. NASAâ€™s strategy for a Mars Sample Return, or MSR, mission remains undecided after the projected cost of the original plan ballooned to $11 billion . If MSR happens at all, itâ€™s now unlikely to launch until the 2030s. Read full article Comments

items.title: Does swearing make you stronger? Science says yes.
items.summary: "A calorie-neutral, drug-free, low-cost, readily available tool for when we need a boost in performance.â€
items.body: If youâ€™re human, youâ€™ve probably hollered a curse word or two (or three) when barking your shin on a table edge or hitting your thumb with a hammer. Perhaps youâ€™ve noticed that this seems to lessen your pain. Thereâ€™s a growing body of scientific evidence that this is indeed the case. The technical term is the â€œ hypoalgesic effect of swearing. â€ Cursing can also improve physical strength and endurance, according to a new paper published in the journal American Psychologist. As previously reported , co-author Richard Stephens, a psychologist at Keele, became interested in studying the potential benefits of profanity after noting his wifeâ€™s â€œunsavory languageâ€ while giving birth and wondered if profanity really could help alleviate pain. â€œSwearing is such a common response to pain. There has to be an underlying reason why we do it,â€ Stephens told Scientific American after publishing a 2009 study that was awarded the 2010 Ig Nobel Peace Prize. For that study, Stephens and his colleagues asked 67 study participants (college students) to immerse their hands in a bucket of ice water. They were then instructed to either swear repeatedly using the profanity of their choice or chant a neutrâ€¦

items.title: Formula 1 is deploying new jargon for 2026
items.summary: Forget DRS, now it's all about corner mode, straight mode, and overtake mode.
items.body: While not quite a separate dialect, Formula 1-speak can be heavy on the jargon at times. They say â€œboxâ€ instead of pit, â€œpower unitâ€ to describe the engine and hybrid system, and thatâ€™s before we get into all the aerodynamics-related expressions like â€œoutwashâ€ and â€œdirty air.â€ Next year is a big technical shakeup for the sport, and it seems weâ€™re getting some new terminology to go with it. So forget your DRS and get ready to talk about Boost mode instead. The F1 car of 2026 will be slightly narrower and slightly lighter than the machines that raced for the last time earlier this month . But not by a huge amount: minimum weight is decreased by 30 kg to 724 kg, the wheelbase is 200 mm shorter at 3,400 mm, and the carâ€™s underfloor is 150 mm narrower than before. The front wing is 100 mm narrower and has just two elements to it, although for the first time in F1 history, this is now an active wing, which works in conjunction with the three-element active rear wing. Active rear wings have been a thing in F1 since the introduction of DRSâ€”the drag reduction systemâ€”in 2011, but now thereâ€™s a philosophical change to how theyâ€™ll work. items.title: The inside story of SpaceXâ€™s historic rocket landing that changed launch forever
items.summary: "It's hard to describe how epic this comeback was after our first Falcon 9 launch failure."
items.body: On Dec. 21, 2015, SpaceX launched the Orbcomm-2 mission on an upgraded version of its Falcon 9 rocket. That night, just days before Christmas, the company successfully landed the first stage for the first time. The story behind this remarkable achievement is nowhere more fully told than in the book Reentry , authored by Ars Technica Senior Space Editor Eric Berger and published in 2024. To mark the tenth anniversary, Ars is reprinting a slightly condensed chapter from the book that tells the inside story of this landing. The chapter begins in June 2015 with a tragedy, the disintegration of a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the CRS-7 cargo supply mission for NASA. It was the first time a Falcon 9 had been lost in flight. Seconds after the Dragon-bearing Falcon 9 rocket broke apart over the Atlantic Ocean, David Giger shouted into his headset, â€œDragon is alive!â€ In the decade since he joined the company straight out of graduate school, Giger had taken on management of the entire Dragon program, reporting directly to Elon Musk. He watched the CRS-7 launch from mission control in Hawthorne not with a particular role, but rather providing a leadership presence. Giger could sense the Dragon miâ€¦

items.title: Physicists 3D-printed a Christmas tree of ice
items.summary: New method uses no freezing technology or refrigeration equipmentâ€”just water and a vacuum.
items.body: Physicists at the University of Amsterdam came up with a really cool bit of Christmas decor: a miniature 3D-printed Christmas tree, a mere 8 centimeters tall, made of ice, without any refrigeration equipment or other freezing technology, and at minimal cost. The secret is evaporative cooling, according to a preprint posted to the physics arXiv. Evaporative cooling is a well-known phenomenon; mammals use it to regulate body temperature. You can see it in your morning cup of hot coffee: the hotter atoms rise to the top of the magnetic trap and â€œjump outâ€ as steam. It also plays a role (along with shock wave dynamics and various other factors) in the formation of â€œ wine tears. â€ Itâ€™s a key step in creating Bose-Einstein condensates. And evaporative cooling is also the main culprit behind the infamous â€œstallâ€ that so frequently plagues aspiring BBQ pit masters eager to make a successful pork butt. The meat sweats as it cooks, releasing the moisture within, and that moisture evaporates and cools the meat, effectively canceling out the heat from the BBQ. Thatâ€™s why a growing number of competitive pit masters wrap their meat in tinfoil after the first few hours (usually when the internalâ€¦

items.title: OpenAIâ€™s new ChatGPT image generator makes faking photos easy
items.summary: New GPT Image 1.5 allows more detailed conversational image editing, for better or worse.
items.body: For most of photographyâ€™s roughly 200-year history, altering a photo convincingly required either a darkroom, some Photoshop expertise, or, at minimum, a steady hand with scissors and glue. On Tuesday, OpenAI released a tool that reduces the process to typing a sentence. Itâ€™s not the first company to do so. While OpenAI had a conversational image-editing model in the works since GPT-4o in 2024, Google beat OpenAI to market in March with a public prototype, then refined it to a popular model called Nano Banana image model (and Nano Banana Pro ). The enthusiastic response to Googleâ€™s image-editing model in the AI community got OpenAIâ€™s attention . OpenAIâ€™s new GPT Image 1.5 is an AI image synthesis model that reportedly generates images up to four times faster than its predecessor and costs about 20 percent less through the API. The model rolled out to all ChatGPT users on Tuesday and represents another step toward making photorealistic image manipulation a casual process that requires no particular visual skills. Read full article Comments

items.title: Man sues cops who jailed him for 37 days for trolling a Charlie Kirk vigil
items.summary: Cops may be fined for jailing a man over his Facebook posts.
items.body: Larry Bushart, a man who was jailed for 37 days for reposting a Trump meme , has now sued the cops who allegedly schemed to keep him imprisoned for as long as possible simply because they disagreed with his point of view. Bushart is a former cop who lost his post-retirement job after a seemingly vengeful sheriff jailed him for trolling a Charlie Kirk vigil post in a Facebook group. Upset that Kirkâ€™s death commanded more attention than other victims of gun violence, Bushart posted a string of memes, among which was an image of Trump with an actual quote saying â€œWe have to get over itâ€ about a 2024 school shooting. Perry County sheriff Nick Weems has since acknowledged that he â€œknewâ€ that the meme referenced a prior school shooting. However, the entire time that Bushart was detained, Weems maintained that Bushartâ€™s post incited â€œmass hysteriaâ€ from parents concerned that he was threatening violence at a local high school. Painting Bushart as indifferent to the supposed hysteria, Weems justified his arrest, as well as the $2 million bond ensuring Bushart couldnâ€™t afford bail and remained behind bars. Read full article Comments

items.title: FCC chair scrubs website after learning it called FCC an â€œindependent agencyâ€
items.summary: Meanwhile, Ted Cruz wants to restrict FCC's power to intimidate broadcasters.
items.body: Federal Communications Commission Chairman Brendan Carr today faced blistering criticism in a Senate hearing for his September threats to revoke ABC station licenses over comments made by Jimmy Kimmel. While Democrats provided nearly all the criticism, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said that Congress should act to restrict the FCCâ€™s power to intimidate news broadcasters. As an immediate result of todayâ€™s hearing , the FCC removed a statement from its website that said it is an independent agency. Carr, who has embraced President Trumpâ€™s declaration that independent agencies may no longer operate independently from the White House, apparently didnâ€™t realize that the website still called the FCC an independent agency. â€œYes or no, is the FCC an independent agency?â€ Sen. Ben Ray LujÃ¡n (D-N.M.) asked. Carr answered that the FCC is not independent, prompting LujÃ¡n to point to a statement on the FCC website calling the FCC â€œan independent US government agency overseen by Congress.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Weâ€™ve finally cracked how to make truly random numbers
items.summary: From machine learning to voting, the workings of the world demand randomisation, but true sources of randomness are surprisingly hard to find. Now quantum mechanics has supplied the answer

items.title: 2025 is the second-hottest year since records began
items.summary: Mean temperatures this year approached 1.5Â°C above the preindustrial average, making it the second hottest year after 2024

items.title: Odd elements in supernova blast might have implications for alien life
items.summary: Some of the elements used by living systems are far more abundant in Cassiopeia A than we thought, hinting that some parts of our galaxy might be more suitable for life than others

items.title: How worried should you be about spending too much time on your phone?
items.summary: Screen time has been linked to all sorts of problems, from depression and obesity to poor sleep. But how worried should you really be? Jacob Aron sifts through the evidence

items.title: What the family drama of interbreeding polar and grizzly bears reveals
items.summary: A hybrid grolar bear saga is unfolding in the Arctic, and the tale of this strange family has much to tell us about nature on our changing planet

items.title: Extreme heat hampers childrenâ€™s early learning
items.summary: Children regularly exposed to temperatures over 30Â°C (86Â°F) have lower scores on literacy and numeracy tests at age 3 to 4, according to UNICEF data from six countries

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: Too busy to meditate? Microdosing mindfulness has big health benefits
items.summary: Small bursts of mindfulness practices lasting a minute or less can have unexpected benefits for those with busy lives - hereâ€™s how

items.title: Are we living in a simulation? This experiment could tell us
items.summary: The idea that we might be living in a simulated reality has worried us for centuries. Now physicists have found some tantalising clues â€“ and devised an experiment that might reveal the truth

items.title: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule for life
items.summary: Astronomers have discovered that 3I/ATLAS is carrying methanol and other chemicals that were probably important in the origin of life

items.title: Tattooing may trigger localised damage to the immune system
items.summary: There is relatively little information on the long-term health effects of tattooing, but a couple of recent studies suggest the art form might trigger prolonged inflammation

items.title: Hunter-gatherer groups are much less egalitarian than they seem
items.summary: There is a widespread belief that altruism and equality drive social behaviour in traditional hunter-gatherer societies, but the truth is more surprising and complex

items.title: Quantum experiment settles a century-old row between Einstein and Bohr
items.summary: Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr had an ongoing rivalry about the true nature of quantum mechanics, and came up with a thought experiment that could settle the matter. Now, that experiment has finally been performed for real

items.title: How Australian teens are planning to get around their social media ban
items.summary: From legal challenges to lesser-known apps, the teenagers of Australia are already preparing to push back against a law that will see under 16s banned from social media

items.title: England's AI World Cup masterplan - from perfecting penalties to powering players
items.summary: BBC Sport hears from inside the England setup about how artificial intelligence is powering plans for next summer's World Cup.

items.title: AI can influence voters' minds. What does that mean for democracy?
items.summary: Voters change their opinions after interacting with an AI chatbot â€“ but, encouragingly, it seems that AIs rely on facts to influence people

items.title: Why is AI making computers and games consoles more expensive?
items.summary: The AI industry consumes vast amounts of energy, fresh water and investor cash. Now it also needs memory chips - the same ones used in laptops, smartphones and games consoles

items.title: Volcano eruption may have led to the Black Death coming to Europe
items.summary: Climate data and historical accounts suggest that crop failures in the 1340s prompted Italian officials to import grain from eastern Europe, and this may have carried in the plague bacterium

items.title: Images reveal the astonishing complexity of the microscopic world
items.summary: From a dragonfly to marine organisms, photographer Michael Benson zoomed in with powerful scanning electron microscopes to take these extraordinary shots for his book Nanocosmos

items.title: Could the super-rich be cloning themselves? And why would they?
items.summary: Nearly three decades since the remarkable cloning of Dolly the sheep, it has all gone quiet on the human cloning front. Michael Le Page wonders what's happening behind the scenes

items.title: Tigers seem to be bouncing back in remote Sumatran jungle
items.summary: Camera traps in an area of the Leuser rainforest patrolled by NGOs spotted 17 tigers in 2023 and 18 Sumatran tigers in 2024, while surveys elsewhere on the island averaged seven

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense

items.title: Ancient human artefacts found near caves in Arabian desert
items.summary: Today, the deserts of the Arabian peninsula are inhospitable â€“ but 100,000 years ago, the area was full of animals and ancient humans

items.title: Why quantum mechanics says the past isnâ€™t real
items.summary: The famous double-slit experiment brings into question the very nature of matter. Its cousin, the quantum eraser experiment, makes us question the very existence of time â€“ and how much we can manipulate it

items.title: Black hole entropy hints at a surprising truth about our universe
items.summary: Two clashing ideas about disorder inside black holes now point to the same strange conclusions, and it could reshape the foundations of how we think about space and time

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: Asteroid Bennu carries all the ingredients for life as we know it
items.summary: We knew from prior analyses that a distant asteroid sampled in 2020 carried all but one of the molecules needed to kick-start life, and researchers have just found the missing ingredient: sugar

items.title: Coral reefs have fuelled severe global warming in Earth's past
items.summary: Over the past 250 million years, periods when coral reef growth has peaked have coincided with big rises in sea temperatures

items.title: We now have a greater understanding of how exercise slows cancer
items.summary: Tumour growth is reduced by exercise due to a shift in the bodyâ€™s metabolism that means muscle cells outcompete cancer cells in the race to get sugar to grow

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life
items.summary: We have long struggled to determine how the first living organisms on Earth came together. Now, surprising evidence hints that poorly understood prions may have been the vital missing ingredient

items.title: Man unexpectedly cured of HIV after stem cell transplant
items.summary: A handful of people with HIV have been cured after receiving HIV-resistant stem cells â€“ but a man who received non-resistant stem cells is also now HIV-free

items.title: Cats can overcome fear of water to benefit from aquatic therapy
items.summary: Vets have developed a training protocol to help cats benefit from water-based rehabilitation therapies, in spite of their natural aversion to water

items.title: The best new science fiction books of December 2025
items.summary: From a new collection of shorter fiction by Brandon Sanderson to Simon StÃ¥lenhagâ€™s new work, via a Stranger Things novel, Decemberâ€™s new sci-fi features some compelling and intriguing offerings

items.title: 'Raise hell' - the fastest bowler you might not have heard of
items.summary: The story of Duncan Spencer, the "frighteningly fast" bowler who could have played for England or Australia.

items.title: Cold-water swimming has benefits for the brain as well as the body
items.summary: There is a growing body of research on the physical benefits of going for a dip in chilly water, but now researchers are starting to find that cold-water swimming may also be reshaping our brains for the better in lasting ways

items.title: The 12 best science fiction books of 2025
items.summary: From drowned worlds to virtual utopias via deep space, wild ideas abound in Emily H. Wilson's picks for her favourite sci-fi reads of the year

items.title: What next for friendly foes who see each other 'more than family'?
items.summary: Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz have dominated menâ€™s tennis in 2025. BBC Sport looks at the evolution of their growing rivalry â€“ and where it could go next.
